children.text: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank: The Warrens are ______ their house by the end of this month.
Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word: Banish
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the underlined word: This book is written by a famous author named G.H. Sullivan.
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the underlined word to fill in the blank: We are blessed with a prudent house keeper, but cursed with an ______ house master.

Parts of a sentence are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the parts in the correct order to form a meaningful sentence: A: by the doctor to drink, E: the lady was compelled, C: such a vile medicine that, D: but killed by him, E: she was all

The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer: Mr. Arun had / written the letter / before the manager arrived.
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech: Ram said, “I watched football.”

options: Ram said that I shall watch football.
Ram said that he had watched football.
Ram said that they watched football.
Ram said that he watches football.

children.text: Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the word ‘Virtue’ from the given sentence: Every person’s actions have an innate power that determines the appropriate reward or punishment in addition to a moral value that produces merit or demerit.

If there is an error in the given sentence, choose the correct answer from the options without changing the tense. One of the four options has same response as the original sentence, which can be chosen in case of agreement with the original sentence: I will have been studying English for three years by the end of this course.

options: I had been studying English for three years by the end of this course.
I have been studying English for three years by the end of this course.
I will have been studying English for three years by the end of this course.
I was studying English for three years by the end of this course.

children.text: Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the underlined word: The detective’s astute observations led to the discovery of crucial evidence, unlike his oblivious partner.
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in active voice: The couple was trolled by everyone.

options: The social media trolled the couple.

children.text: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech: He said, “I am going to the party tonight.”

options: He said that he would go to the party that night.
He said that he was going to the party tonight.
He said that he was going to the party that night.
He said that he is going to the party tonight.

children.text: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank: Siraj threw a stone to destroy the ______ built by the bird in a tree.
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence: Whether she wishes to relocate to Mumbai or continues to live here are her personal decisions.

The following sentence has been divided into five segments. The first segment has no error. Select the option that has the segment with the grammatical error: It began / to rain / as soon as / she steps out of / the movie theatre.
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in active voice: Srikar had been promised good support by Mahitha.

options: Mahitha will have promised Srikar good support.
Mahitha has promised Srikar good support.
Mahitha had promised good support to Srikar.
Mahitha promises good support to Srikar.

children.text: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank: A city on a hill ______ be hidden.

Identify the errors in the given sentence and choose the sentence that rectifies these errors: The boy you met on an train last night was quite impressed by you. He has expressed his wish to work under you.

options: The boy you met on train last night was quite impressed by you. He has expressed his wish to work under you.
The boy you met on the train last night was quite impressed by you. He has expressed his wish to work under you.
Boy you met on the train last night was quite impressed by you. He has expressed his wish to work under you.
An boy you met on the train last night was quite impressed by you. He has expressed his wish to work under you.

children.text: Select the alternative from the given options that best expresses the same sentence in active/passive voice: How did you pay the bill?

options: How is the bill paid by you?
How the bill is to be paid by you?
How the bill has been paid by you?
How was the bill paid by you?

children.text: Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence: Radha and Sheela have been knowing each other since they were children.
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment without changing its meaning in the given sentence: He gave his heart and soul to make the entire show a success.
Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word: Enrage
Select the most appropriate option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: Do not mind Hari’s insulting words.

options: Let Hari’s insulted words be minded.
Let not Hari’s insulting words be minded.
Let’s don’t mind Hari’s insulting words.
Let Hari not mind the insulting words.

children.text: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: These days most of the researchers conduct research with the help of internet.

options: These days the research is conducted with the help of internet by most of the researchers.
These days most of the researchers are conducting their research with the help of internet.
These days most of the research is being done with the help of internet.
These days the research has been done with the help of internet by most of the researchers.

children.text: Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word. Stretch
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: The interviewers were asking difficult questions.

options: Difficult questions are being asked by the interviewers.
Difficult questions are asked by the interviewers.
Difficult questions were asked by the interviewers.
Difficult questions were being asked by the interviewers.

children.text: The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, select ‘No error’ as your answer: (a) This is book/ (b) you are/ (c) searching for / (d) No error
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: Are they watching the programmes?

options: Are the programmes being watched by them?
Have the programmes been watched by them?
Had the programmes been watched by them?
Were the programmes being watched by them?

children.text: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech: The tourist said, “Wow! what a wonderful view.”

options: The tourist exclaimed with joy that it was a wonderful view.
The tourist explained with joy that the view is wonderful.
The tourist said that the view is wonderful.
The tourist told what a wonderful view it is.

children.text: Select the most appropriate option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: The helper threw the trash in the dustbin.

options: The trash has been thrown in the dustbin by the helper.
The trash is thrown in the dustbin by the helper.
The trash had been thrown in the dustbin by the helper.
The trash was thrown in the dustbin by the helper.

children.text: Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph: a. Nowadays, society has become corrupted by cunning, manipulative and toxic people. b. The responsibility should be taken by mentally strong people. c. There lies a responsibility for others to make society a better place to live in. d. Being robust, they can devote their time or resources to change noxious individuals.
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error: When a beggar appeared, I offered him / an one rupee coin / but he did not take it.

options: but he did not take it

children.text: Select the most appropriate idiomatic expression that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence: Today’s managers’ meeting has given me a lot to think about as I decide whether or not to stay with this company.
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word: Accelerate
Select the most appropriate option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech: She said, “I cannot call you at this time.”

options: She said that she could not call me at that time.
She said that she cannot call me at that time.
She said that she would not call me at this time.
She said that she could not call me this time.

children.text: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech: They said that they were practising for the next annual function.

options: They said, “They were practising for the next annual function.”
They said, “We are practising for the next annual function.”
They said, “We are practising for tomorrow’s annual function.”
They said, “We have been practising for the next annual function.”

children.text: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in reported speech: Rathan said, “I have written a poem.”

options: Rathan said that he has written a poem.
Rathan said that I had written a poem.
Rathan said that he wrote a poem.
Rathan said that he had written a poem.

children.text: Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence: Anya was a empath and had accurate intuitions regarding other people’s feelings.
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error: The committee’s decision / have been / a topic / of controversy.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank: The tree lost many of its ______ in the heavy rain and storm.
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech: The traffic police told me that I couldn’t park my two-wheeler there.

options: The traffic police said to me, “I can’t park my two-wheeler there.”
The traffic police told me, “I couldn’t park my two-wheeler here.”
The traffic police said to me, “You can’t park your two-wheeler here.”
The traffic police said, “Do not park the two-wheeler here.”

children.text: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in reported speech: Mohan said, “I shall go as soon as it is possible.”

options: Mohan said that he would go as soon as it is possible.
Mohan said that he will go as soon as it is possible.
Mohan said that he would go as soon as it was possible.
Mohan said that he will go as soon as it was possible.

children.text: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank: A dam is a barrier that stops the flow of water and results in the creation of a ______.
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech: The traveller asked the owner if he could stay in that tavern. The peasant replied that he could.

options: The traveller said, “Could I stay in this tavern?” The peasant replied, “He should.”
The traveller said, “May I stay in this tavern?” The peasant replies, “You can.”
The traveller said, “Can I stay in this tavern?” The peasant replied, “You can.”
The traveller said, “Can I stay in this tavern?” The peasant replied, “She could.”

children.text: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech: He said that it would be fun if I could join.

options: He said, “It will be fun if you can join.”
He said, “It will have been fun if you had joined.”
He said, “It will have been fun if I could have joined.”
He said, “It will have been fun if I had joined.”

children.text: The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error: Sachin and Sehwag are / great batsmen / but the former is greater / than latter.
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech: My aunt said that they had shifted to a new house.

options: “I am shifting to a new house,” said my aunt.
“We will be shifting to a new house,” said my aunt.
“We are shifting to a new house,” said my aunt.
“We have shifted to a new house,” said my aunt.

children.text: Identify the error in the following sentence: The police are searching about the missing jewellery.

Parts of sentences are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the parts in the correct order to form a meaningful paragraph. The first part ‘R.’ is fixed: R. Mahatma Gandhi led a long struggle against untouchability A. Dr B R Ambedkar, the father of the Indian Constitution, belonged to the lower B. Such as entry into temples and public places C. And worked for the welfare of the so called lower castes D. Caste and made many efforts to secure basic rights for them
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: Mrs. Sandhaya teaches us English.

options: English is taught to us by Mrs. Sandhaya.
English has been taught to us by Mrs. Sandhaya.
English was being taught to us by Mrs. Sandhaya.
English is being taught to us by Mrs. Sandhaya.

children.text: Select the most appropriate form of the bracketed verb in the following sentence to fill in the blank: If only we ______ (has) started earlier, we would be there now.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank: Our environment is facing a severe crisis like never before. Any recklessness in this regard could prove ______ to life on Earth.
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute (replace) the bracketed segment in the following sentence: I look forward (see) you soon.
Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word: Divine
Select the most appropriate meaning of the underlined idiom: Ron always blows his own trumpet by mentioning his academic achievements.

options: To talk proudly about one’s success
To blow air into an instrument
To save one’s money with great effort using different means
To ignore someone in the presence of others

children.text: Select the most appropriate meaning of the underlined idiom: Meera wanted to prove to those around her that she was not a fair-weather friend.

The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer: A courage gives / enormous strength to people / to fight for what they want.

options: to fight for what they want

children.text: Select the most appropriate synonym of the underlined word: Your silly tricks will not impress me.
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: Mr. Varun had answered all the questions.

options: All the questions had been answered by Mr. Varun.
All the questions have been answered by Mr. Varun.
All the questions are answered by Mr. Varun.
All the questions were answered by Mr. Varun.

children.text: The given sentence is divided into four segments. Select the option that has the segment with a grammatical error: Shyamali is / very / careful for / her health.
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word: Curiosity
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in reported speech: Ammu said, “How brilliant I am!”

options: Ammu exclaimed that she was being brilliant.
Ammu exclaimed that she is brilliant.
Ammu exclaimed that she was brilliant.
Ammu exclaimed that she has been brilliant.

children.text: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank: Our crops depend on the rainy season. Before the monsoon begins, farmers in communities begin their work in the fields. They irrigate their grounds and grow a variety of crops ______ for this season using the natural water supply.
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: Who is making such a loud noise?

options: By whom is such a loud noise being made?
By whom has such a loud noise been made?
By whom is such loud noise made?
By whom was such loud noise being made?

children.text: Substitute the underlined word-segment with the most appropriate idiom: Lack of funds is the main obstacle for the company’s growth.
The given sentence is divided into four segments. Select the segment with the grammatical error: Radha climbed the / ladder cautious, / but she fell off / despite being careful.
Select the most appropriate meaning of the given idiom: Get your act together
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in active voice: The telephone was invented by Graham Bell in the second half of the 18th Century.

options: Graham Bell has invented the telephone in the second half of the 18th Century.
Graham Bell invents the telephone in the second half of the 18th Century.
Graham Bell invented the telephone in the second half of the 18th Century.
Graham Bell will have invented the telephone in the second half of the 18th Century.

children.text: The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error: John is really / good in / playing / the piano.

Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank: Spending quality time with friends and family is also ______ to have a healthy daily routine. These happy moments release happy hormones in the body.

Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 1: Presently, a soprano voice of richness and depth floated from the open windows of the parlour, resonating (1) ______ the darkening greenery.

Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 2: All at once it was as if the entire scene before them was (2) ______ by that voice, infused with unexpected life: the western sky, streaked with bands of pale gold and purple; the two houses, standing grey and disconsolate against that sky; the (3) ______ of trees casting deep black shadows here and there across the ground.

Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 3: The same voice that (4) ______ everything suddenly to life also drew them into another, much deeper world: a world that was normally hidden, a world that (5) ______ into eternity.

Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 4: The same voice that (4) ______ everything suddenly to life also drew them into another, much deeper world: a world that was normally hidden, a world that (5) ______ into eternity.

Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 5: The same voice that (4) ______ everything suddenly to life also drew them into another, much deeper world: a world that was normally hidden, a world that (5) ______ into eternity.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 1.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 2.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 3.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 4.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 5.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 1.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 2.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 3.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 4.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 5.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 1.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 2.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 3.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 4.
Select the most appropriate option to fill in blank number 5.
Which two groups of people settled in the island after 1600 AD?
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word in the context of the passage.
Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word from the passage.
The passage talks about two groups of people: one which was peaceful by nature and one which wasn’t. List them in that order.
Which of the following statements can be inferred from the passage?

options: Both the Arawaks and Caribs had permanent chiefs.
The Arawaks first arrived at Saint Maarten around 1300 AD.
The Carib tribe defeated the French in 1600 AD.
The Arawaks first arrived at Saint Maarten around 1000 AD.

children.text: What can be inferred about the monkeys’ behaviour after the incident with the elephants?

options: They only play less harmful pranks.
They continue to play pranks on the elephants.
They only play pranks during certain times of the day.

children.text: Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word.
Select the most appropriate title for the passage.

options: The Great Elephant Uprising: A Cautionary Tale
Monkeying Around: A Tale of Mischief and Pranks
Trouble in the Trees: A Monkey’s Mischief

children.text: Identify the tone of the passage.
What did the elephants do to teach the monkeys a lesson?

options: They started shaking the tree with all their might.
They threw bananas back at the monkeys.
